body: Can you confirm that after downgrading to 0.3.3, the startup is fixed again? Or is it possible that this was due to a separate change in your system?
I did exactly what you asked. I found Emacs startup slows down after a system upgrade, so I tried downgrading alacritty to 0.3.3 and it is fast again.

If you start a selection while waiting for it to finish loading, does that cause Emacs to load immediately? If there's just an issue with Alacritty not redrawing, forcing a redraw like this might help.
Ah, I think that's exactly what happened. I can start typing or do any other thing immediately, and the content will show up.
And `alacritty --version` confirms that you are on at least 0.4.0?
Yes. I'm at 0.4.0.
Hm, that's unusual. Do you have a Rust toolchain installed? If so I think it would be worthwhile to test the latest master.

I just built alacritty manually (at commit e99057b), the problem is the same. I thought maybe the old `alacritty.yml` from 0.3.3 causes the problem, so I removed it, and Emacs starts up fast both in alacritty provided by my OS and built by myself. I'll look into it to find what's the reason.

It's caused by these 2 lines:

```
env:
  TERM: xterm-24bit
```

I can't remember exactly why I did this, but it's for true color in terminal Emacs. If I comment out these lines, there will be only 8 colors. Btw, `xterm-256color` also causes the lag.
Have you tried the `alacritty` terminfo?
Yes. `alacritty-terminfo` is installed, and if I don't set `TERM` in `alacritty.yml`, `$ echo $TERM` shows `alacritty`. Emacs can only use 8 colors in this case.

The `alacritty` terminfo is 256color, the other supported terminfo is `alacritty-direct`. If Alacritty is having issues with any other terminfo, there is no support for that. We can only support the terminfos we control, so it's impossible to guarantee compatibility with anything else.

Having only 8 colors with the `alacritty` and `xterm-256color` terminfo sounds like your emacs might be messed up though. It has been a while since I've tried running emacs, but I don't think that was any problem for me.

> the other supported terminfo is `alacritty-direct`.

If I use `alacritty-direct`, Emacs says this when startup:

```
emacs: Terminal type "alacritty-direct" is not powerful enough to run Emacs.
It lacks the ability to position the cursor.
```

> Having only 8 colors with the `alacritty` and `xterm-256color` terminfo...

Maybe I'm not clear on that, but I can have 256 colors with `xterm-256color`, and true color with `xterm-24bit`. Only `alacritty` has the problem.

> It has been a while since I've tried running emacs, but I don't think that was any problem for me.

I've been using alacritty for several months, and I always remember that `alacritty` terminfo gives me 8 colors in Emacs, and I have to change the `TERM` to `xterm-24bit` or `xterm-256color` to have more colors. Could you test it again?

> The alacritty terminfo is 256color

 So, is Emacs supposed to have 256 colors if I use `alacritty` terminfo?

*Update:* Here's a hint, use `M-x list-colors-display` to find how many colors Emacs can show.

> So, is Emacs supposed to have 256 colors if I use alacritty terminfo?

Yes. The `alacritty` terminfo is a fork of `xterm-256color`.

Okay, I've tested it again by copying `xterm-256color` to the name `alacritty-256color` and started emacs using a 1:1 identical file, just under a different name.

Turns out that Emacs seems to depend on the name of the terminfo file, rather than the content of the file itself, which means this is an emacs problem. If emacs fixes that mess, everything will work properly just the way it works with xterm-256color.

For 24-bit color, `TERM=alacritty-direct` is what should be used.

However, you need to convince Emacs to treat alacritty as an xterm clone, by doing
```lisp
(add-to-list 'term-file-aliases '("alacritty" . "xterm"))
```
 (having `alacritty` is enough and will cover both `TERM=alacritty` and `TERM=alacritty-direct`).

That said, you might still experience a delay. There are a couple of sequences where Alacritty's responses doesn't match what Emacs expects:

* `\e[>0c` - Emacs expects `\e[>N1;N2;N3c`, where N1 represents the terminal type (xterm responds with 41 - vt420), N2 is the xterm version (e.g. 347), and N3 is 0. Emacs' regex requires N3==0, but the other could be more or less anything, though is does use N2 to determine which features it should enable. It also special cases responses from e.g. Gnome Terminal and screen, but otherwise expects an "xterm-like" response.

* `\e]11;?\e\\` (report background color). Emacs expects an ST terminator in the response (`\e\\`), while Alacritty terminates with BEL (btw, xterm parrots the query's terminator in its responses). This _might_ be what causes the temporary hang; Emacs is waiting for an ST terminator that never comes, but thankfully times out after a while.

Note: using BEL as response terminator will **not** work with Emacs: https://debbugs.gnu.org/cgi/bugreport.cgi?bug=36879#11

> Note: using BEL as response terminator will not work with Emacs: https://debbugs.gnu.org/cgi/bugreport.cgi?bug=36879#11

Specifically:

> Emacs uses BEL (C-g) as INTR char, which means that not
> only is special effort required to avoid having it quit the current
> elisp code -- this could have been done using inhibit-quit -- but when
> the pty receives the BEL from XTerm, it immediately discards unread
> characters and raises SIGINT.

It might be worthwhile to mirror the terminator of the original request sequence, though as far as I know that would only be a pleasantry, since both should be properly understood by the application.

It seems that Emacs is doing its best not to play nicely with non-xterm terminfos, so I'm not sure if there's any point in bothering to play nice with it.

I don't think I've seen other applications complaining about this, so it would likely only slightly improve the situation with applications that already do not try to play nice.

> It seems that Emacs is doing its best not to play nicely with non-xterm terminfos, so I'm not sure if there's any point in bothering to play nice with it.

It doesn't actually use the terminfo - it only uses the name to determine which lisp extension code to load to further query the terminal.

(_edit_: is _does_ use terminfo for basic stuff like which sequences to use to move the cursor, delete/insert chars etc. But here it doesn't care whether "xterm" is in the terminfo name or not.)

But yes, the querying code does make certain assumptions. However, in most cases, it wont matter that you reply with something it doesn't understand because the feature it is probing for is xterm specific.

> I don't think I've seen other applications complaining about this, so it would likely only slightly improve the situation with applications that already do not try to play nice.

Emacs is unusual, I think, in that it uses BEL (`C-g`) as INTR. The default is of course `C-c`.

~I do believe that the only "required" change is to mirror the terminator. The rest can be configured in Emacs~. Alacritty needs to implement `CSI > Ps c` - see https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/3091#issuecomment-565549380.

On a side note: even though you should recognize both BEL and ST, xterm calls BEL legacy and mirrors it simply to please "old" applications (or something to that effect - there's a comment about it in the xterm sources).

> On a side note: even though you should recognize both BEL and ST, xterm calls BEL legacy and mirrors it simply to please "old" applications (or something to that effect - there's a comment about it in the xterm sources).

Yeah, fair enough. I guess support for super, super ancient applications that do not get any patches anymore might make this a relevant change. It's crazy that Emacs is one of those, but I guess that's just how it goes sometimes.

rename.to: Mirror escape terminator for legacy support

body:
> It's crazy that Emacs is one of those

Depends on how you look at it. It uses ST itself, and wants ST in the response, not BEL. so in that sense it is modern.

As to why it configures BEL to be the INTR character, _that_ is likely for super super ancient reasons ;)
